Residential areas are made up of houses, of various sizes, and smaller apartment buildings and condominiums. Some properties contain single-family homes, while others contain duplexes. This is true even within my immediately neighborhood, so there is also no lack of diversity in regards to housing options. Similarly, the neighborhood is made up of people of varying ages, and to be perfectly honest, I am not familiar with the majority of my neighbors. It is not really a tight-knit community these days, although I have many memories from my childhood of playing outside with my next-door neighbor, and a few other friends from the neighborhood, who were all close to my age.
“Where is everything?” she asked as we drove past the corn fields which filled the horizon. “This is it!” I said, knowing she’d be in shock of the sparseness of the open landscape. She was from a town in which the grocery store was a 5 minute walk from her house--she’d never seen this much open space in her life. Taken back by the ubiquity of corn fields, I shared with her what it was like to grow up in rural Ohio, and in that moment, she finally knew who I was and where I came from. Driving down a two-lane country road, you will reach a quarry which is filled with water. Just past it is the small development I live in. The houses are mostly composed of brick and stucco. All the houses have at least a half an acre of land to themselves which everyone takes pride in maintaining. During springtime, annually planted flowers are abundant along with the midwestern trees that change with every season. The driveways are all filled with the highest end Mercedes Benz luxury cars that glisten in the midday sun after a good, old-fashioned car wash. Continuing along the road toward my grey stucco home, my Korean neighbor is always outside with a friendly face. He tends to spend the entire day mowing his lawn and can be heard singing over his mower’s hum. Everyone in the neighborhood gets a laugh out of him, but he is always genuine and an amazing person with a unique history. He has grown older and has lost some of his wit as he aged. In his past he was a doctor and usually blends in with the grass and his John Deer Zero Turn mower. Finally, you will reach my home. In the side yard, geese are abundant and are chased by our Terrier. Out back, there is a small stream that feeds into the quarry. Here, you can hear bullfrogs, the stream, and the occasional “moo” from the nearby farms. Across the handmade wooden bridge is an untouched oasis filled with naturally growing trees, herbs, and wildflowers. Here was where I spent most of my childhood. From building tree forts to ‘hunting’ animals (which mostly consisted of chasing them), there was always something to do and usually a neighborhood child available for friendship. The winters in my small town can be painfully brutal, yet there is nothing more beautiful. The yard transforms from a sea of green into an empty wilderness. The trees that once housed vibrant pink, purple, and orange flowers turn into barren skeletons of bark. When blessed with the occasional snowfall, a winter wonderland appears overnight. The backyard is lined with snow angels made by my little sister, and snowmen. My sister and I fought frequently as kids, and during the winter, snowballs were our weapon of choice. We’d build massive igloo-like forts to house our weapons, usually with branches, like an arsenal. In our own little wonderland was where we played pretend during a time where nothing else mattered. We were just young kids without a care in the world.
transformed_texts:
This land aint got no gleaming towers nor the bright lights of commerce that other folk speak of. Just farmland stretching out like a tired blanket til it meets them tourist towns. No malls here. No Walmarts. No chain restaurants with their neon signs blazing against the night sky. Everything you need is a drive away through the empty country.

The waters though. The waters hold something ancient and true. Two lakes lap at the edges of our town like giant mirrors laid flat against the earth. Lake Michigan to one side vast and cold, Lake Charlevoix to the other. Everywhere you turn theres sand waiting for bare feet, water waiting to swallow your reflection.

The houses stand apart from each other like old soldiers who've seen too much. Aint no matching faces here. Each one tells its own story. Some got fresh paint and new windows, others wear their age like medals. Most got basements you can see from the road, dug deep into the Michigan clay. Aluminum siding gone gray with time covers most, colors faded like old photographs left in the sun.

Children run wild in the streets like scattered birds. Dogs tug at their leashes. Bikes leave thin trails in the dust. Folk here know each other. Know who belongs and who dont. They wave from their grills, smoke rising up like prayers. They nod as they pass, dogs padding alongside.

The yards stay trim, grass cut low like a military haircut. No dead leaves allowed to gather and rot. Plants stand in neat rows like prisoners. Its not beautiful in the way that makes people stop and stare, but beautiful in the way that makes them want to stay. Safe. Quiet. Like the world before it went wrong.

The jail squats at the edge of town, gray and watchful. The health department beside it like some kind of promise. Planes drone overhead from the small airport, their shadows crossing yards where baseball games echo from nearby fields. The recycling center hums its own quiet song of preservation.

Ice cream can be had by foot, and downtown aint far if youre of a mind to walk it. Children pedal their bikes to the park like pilgrims to a shrine, eight blocks through the heart of what we call home. This here's a place where the world still makes sense. Where people can still find their way back to what matters. A place where the day ends soft and quiet, like a prayer whispered in the dark.

The houses stood like sentinels in the dead heat of morning. Row upon row of them identical and stark against the pallid sky. No variation in their countenance save what the homeowners association would permit in their godlike governance of such things. Small patches of grass lay before each dwelling trimmed and manicured like cemetery plots. Gravel beds with their decorative stones bleached white in the sun. The driveways short and perfect leading to garages that could shelter two vehicles and nothing more.

They'd paved these roads not long past. Fresh concrete unmarred by time or neglect stretched out before you like a river of bone. No potholes here. No imperfection that might speak to the passage of years or the weight of vehicles gone before. Some dwellings rose two stories tall but most crouched low against the earth as if wary of drawing attention to themselves.

The mailboxes stood gathered at the street's end like prisoners awaiting judgment. Not separate markers for each home as you might expect but a congregation of metal boxes bound together, each secured by its own key. Two larger chambers for parcels that might come. The association had ordained it thus and so it remained.

At the city's edge where suburban order gave way to rural chaos the neighborhood sprawled vast and purposeful. Swimming pools lay behind iron gates available to any who lived here and could prove their belonging. Walking paths wound through the emptiness like the tracks of ancient creatures long extinct. You could walk your dog there or take evening constitutional without need of designated parkland. The retired folk who made up most of the population would watch from their windows, guardians of this manufactured peace. Young professionals moved among them like ghosts, outnumbered but tolerated.

The city itself lay fifteen minutes distant by automobile, a sprawling thing that somehow maintained its small-town pretense. One mall stood there, neither grand nor humble but sufficient to its purpose. Markets of various persuasion lined the streets from the organic temples of the wealthy to the bare-bones outlets where the poor sought sustenance.

This was a place of safety and order. A place where man had imposed his will upon the landscape and called it good. The swimming pools gleamed like blind eyes in the sun. The walking trails wound their way through carefully managed wilderness. And all of it lay just far enough from commerce to maintain its isolation while remaining within reach of every chain store and market that modern life demanded. This was civilization's compromise with chaos, and it endured.

First time I heard tell of the place was through voices speaking of the vanished. Strange thing to hear in a city where folk paid thousands just to lay their heads. None I knew spoke of such tales. Maybe it's the weight of living crushing down. Some nights you hear the sobbing through the walls, through the floors. Folk learn to scrape by. Learn to love the smell of other people's castoffs, mothballed clothes and broken toys laid out on folding tables in the dust. The smell of youth dies quiet. Some take to smoking. Some just forget what clean air tastes like. But the flea market smell, it stays. Settles in like death. Smells like forgotten magazines yellowing on a dead piano. Gets in the leather and wont wash out no matter what you do.

Three secondhand stores within walking. Start at the far end, you can work your way through two charity shops, the library with its musty books, rare book dealer, curio shop with its shelves of dead men's treasures. Downtown's thick with bodies and machines, morning till night, but step inside them stores and the world goes quiet as a tomb. Good place to lose yourself. More of them coming every year, the bodies and machines. Growing city, they say. Some big company dealing in clicks and packages made its home here. Like New York in a way. Everyone got their own heading, don't nobody ask much of you. Can keep to yourself, quiet-like, independent. Not like down South where caring means prying. Here you can keep your walls up long as you please and the city just rolls past like waves on a dead shore.

Life still moves though. Got a piano player next door, couple singers upstairs always working their scales. Less strangers sharing walls than a kind of family. Come together when needs must. Share the birthdays, the funerals, the hard times. Lucky in a way. Most of them treat me fair and I do the same. Clean up after myself, share food when I can. Trade favors like mail delivery. See them smile when I pass and think maybe they're glad of me like I'm glad of them. Living in this great concrete maze of modern times but it's them makes me think I ain't totally lost my way after all.

The town lies just beyond where the city's reach ends. A small place. Midwestern. We live on the east side where the poorest folk dwell in homes worth little more than kindling. Rental signs stand like sentries on grassless yards. But there aint no ugliness here like you might expect. Folk still nod and speak when you pass. They remember such things.

Violence visits sometimes like an unwelcome relative that wont leave. Gunshots in the night. Blood on sidewalks. The neighbors boy got killed outside some bar last year. His mother still sits on that porch watching nothing. We lost a few things left outside but nothing more. The real killer here is that white powder. Fentanyl. It takes them quick and quiet. Town's got places for them that want help. Teaching folks how to bring the dead back with that Narcan. Some make it. Most dont.

The boy goes to school where they treat him right despite his differences. Good people there. Teachers that still care about such things. Parents meeting regular to plan things for the children. More than twenty of every hundred here cant feed their own so the school feeds em all. Breakfast and lunch. No child marked for being poor.

The council men build their gardens and fix their roads but mostly in the middle of town or the west side where the money lives. East side gets forgotten like an old dog under the porch. But we been here sixteen years in this little house that aint worth much but keeps the rain out. Stores enough to get by. Good people mostly. Cant imagine being nowhere else though sometimes at night I hear them shots and wonder if the devil aint living here too somewhere in them shadows.

The neighborhood rises like some ancient beast from the belly of the city, its spine a ridge of weathered buildings crowned with histories dark and deep. Seven stories up I dwell, across from where the theater stands sentinel, its marquee dead and silent now like the eyes of something long buried. Down the slope there's a place where folk gather when the nights turn warm, an arcade bar they call it, though it bears little resemblance to the penny arcades of old. They queue there in the summer months, June and July mostly, standing patient and solemn like mourners at some perpetual wake.

The park lies northward, vast and empty save for the concrete that rings it like a collar, steps carved into its throat like the marks of some ancient ceremony. Winter brings the dispossessed, their tents arrayed in rows precise as headstones. Rain comes more often than snow, beating against canvas like nature's own dirge. They huddle close, these wanderers, seeking warmth in numbers, closer to the heart of things than out there in what they call the jungle. The family center stands like a beacon, offering water and soap and brief moments of dignity.

But it aint the architecture that speaks to me, nor them proud old buildings that march down toward the sea. It's the people carrying their histories like scripture. Hilltop, they say, was once mean as a rattler, gang violence flowing through its streets like poison. Federal men came through with their badges and guns, sweeping clean what couldn't be cleaned. The stories persist, passed down like dark gospels, mother to child, stranger to stranger.

The people here, they tend their streets like gardens, though outsiders still speak of danger. White folk, they say, best clear out after dark. But that's just echoes, old fears speaking with dead tongues. Maybe it's the darkness in my own blood that lets me pass, or maybe Hilltop knows its own - them that understand how fear and ignorance breed like rats in the walls of this supposed melting pot paradise.

This is home now. These streets know me like I know them. Strangers offer warmth more often than harm. The laundry woman keeps her lights burning when the rain comes horizontal and mean. I've sat against cold concrete, thinking myself invisible as ash, only to have some passerby reach down with a five-dollar bill and words sweet as scripture: you're beautiful, they say, you're valuable. And in this place, in this moment, it rings true as gospel.

They came to this place when he was thirteen summers old, before the boy had learned the ways of men. The houses stood like sentinels, two stories tall and identical in their suburban uniformity, stretched out along the asphalt road that wound through the development like a black river. The boy had no friends then but time brought him two companions, one who lived two doors down and another who dwelt further along the street. Both gone now but their ghosts remained.

The neighborhood stood unchanged. Like some photograph yellowed with age but preserved in its essence. Children's voices carried on the warm wind whenever the sun showed itself, their laughter echoing off vinyl siding and carefully tended lawns. Most days the streets lay quiet. No quarrels with neighbors. No strife. A place where solitude was respected save when aid was needed. Packages left on porches remained untouched, as if protected by some unspoken covenant between the dwellers of this place.

There was a park. Not more than a hundred yards distant. A place of memories both blessed and cursed. Where basketballs had arced through summer evenings and footballs spiraled against gray autumn skies. Where blood had flowed from the boy's nose one cold afternoon, crimson drops staining white winter ground. Now he brought his cousin's children there, watching them swing and slide in their innocent joy, their excitement pure and untainted by time's passing.

The streets around teemed with the foods of many nations. Chinese. Indian. Mexican. Italian. All within walking distance though most now summoned their sustenance through glowing screens and waiting drivers. Fast food joints squatted on corners like gargoyles, identical to those in every other suburb in this vast land. Pizza parlors too, their red signs glowing in the dusk.

Stores lined the streets like trading posts of old. Dry cleaners. Drug stores facing each other across the road like duelists. A grocery store bearing a name known only to those who dwelled in these northern territories. And there was the Indian store, its shelves stocked with spices and strange grains, preserved foods in jars like specimens in some exotic museum.

He thought of other neighborhoods he'd read about. Places where darkness dwelt in men's hearts and evil walked abroad in daylight. This place was not like those. Here was peace of a sort. Here was home.

The college stands near where I live, a blessing of sorts in this godless stretch of urban decay. Apartment buildings rise like ancient monoliths against a gray sky, their facades weathered and worn by time's merciless march. Between them stand the bars and eateries where the young gather, counting their meager coins for watered-down spirits. One such establishment recently took on a new name, as if christening could wash away its sins of overpriced libations and indifferent service.

The people here exist in two tribes: the students, temporary as morning frost, and the poor souls anchored by poverty to these crumbling walls. Children too, their voices carrying across concrete and asphalt from the schoolyard nearby. My neighbors remain strangers by choice, though their marijuana smoke seeps through walls like some spectral presence. Management's solution: a plastic box spewing artificial freshness, a joke told in the language of corporate impotence.

Down the road stand new buildings, false promises wrapped in cheap materials and high rent. Their walls thin as playing cards, built by men who knew nothing of permanence. A restaurant serves microwaved sustenance on paper plates, a temple to disposable living. Beside it squats a gas station, where desperate men trade hours of their lives for dollars.

The city, in its infinite wisdom, laid new concrete paths and planted grass in strips, as if nature could be parceled and contained. My building hunkers beneath ancient trees, some now reduced to stumps like broken teeth in a dying mouth. Behind us lies 43rd Street, a darker reflection of our own, where cracked sidewalks spider-web beneath feet and buildings wear their shame openly. Crime blooms there like black mold, though it seeps across boundaries, respecting no borders we devise.

Yet I remain, tethered by economics and convenience to this place. The university stands within walking distance, and buses carry the carless to their destinations like modern-day ferrymen. This is my station now, among the concrete and the dying trees, in this purgatory between poverty and promise.

The duplexes stood like yellow sentinels in the dead end road, their white porches gleaming against metal roofs green as summer grass. They'd built them to look separate but they wasnt. Folk gathered most evenings at the end of whatever drive suited them, speaking soft words while their young ones made chalk marks on the concrete or sent their kites up into that vast blue nothing. Like some forgotten time it was. A place where the mechanical world hadnt yet laid its cold hand.

Fields stretched out beyond the houses and trees rose up black against the sky where clouds moved like great white ships. But the weather it had turned. Last night the sirens came wailing through the darkness and we knew what was coming. Found myself in the bathtub clutching the little dog and whatever treasures I thought to save while the big one paced the living room, barking at demons he couldn't see. The hail came then. Like God's own marbles hitting the earth. When it was done the road steamed like some creature breathing its last and the temperature had dropped from ninety-two to seventy-five quick as a thought. The hail melted where it struck the burning pavement and then the sun broke through and the rain came again and with it two rainbows arced across the sky like some biblical covenant.

The houses stood quiet for a time after, till folk began to drift back from wherever they'd sheltered. Then it was like always. Women watching their young ones while dinner cooked inside. Different from New Hampshire this place was, forty minutes outside Charlotte where I'd come to rest. The southern voices soft and strange like music from another country. Two bedrooms and two baths in each unit though some were smaller inside than others which didnt make no sense but that's how it was.

Behind the houses there was a pond where swimming wasnt allowed and I'd walk there sometimes seeing deer moving like ghosts through the morning mist while bullfrogs sang their ancient songs. Roosters called from the surrounding farms each dawn and sometimes in the evening a donkey would bray into the growing dark like he was telling the world he still drew breath. A good place it was. A place a body could call home.

Ten years now in this place. Memory holds the move from Riverdale to Stockbridge like a photograph faded at the edges. Tears came then, for what was lost and what was loved, though mama and daddy had their reasons. Better schools they said. Better houses. Places where the darkness of the city couldn't reach.

Time passed like water through fingers. Made friends and enemies both, though neighbors remained strangers save for Mr. Glen and Dennis living adjacent. Good folk. Like blood almost. Remember Mr. Glen's wedding clear as yesterday, him taking another wife. Caught the white garter when Ms. Veda sent it sailing through the lamplight. Danced with Marsharii that night, her face young and full of promise. Never saw her after. World swallows some whole.

The streets here wind like snakes in summer grass. GPS helps now but before it was just wandering. Me and Kason and Curtis, we'd lose ourselves in video games, in the simple pleasure of being young and alive. Sometimes I'd walk alone to the park where the trees stand sentinel. Brought sticks from the hardware store to practice balance, brought the wooden sword too. Something holy in that solitude.

Courts there for basketball and tennis both, empty now but waiting. Daddy and Mr. Graves taught us tennis years back, worked us till our muscles burned and our hearts sang. Good times those were. Simple times.

Reckon there's more stories buried in these streets than I could tell in a day. But these are the ones that stick like burrs to the soul, that won't shake loose no matter how far you walk. And somewhere ahead the future waits, patient as stone, holding whatever comes next in its dark hands.

Johnston lay there in the South Carolina heat like some forgotten outpost of civilization. A town that breathed peaches. The welcome sign proclaimed it proud, Peach Capital of the World, though the world had long since moved on from such declarations. Fields stretched out beyond sight, peach trees standing sentinel over the cattle that grazed in the spaces between. Houses set back from the road like afterthoughts, metal roofs gleaming under the merciless sun or gray shingles dulled by time and weather, each dwelling an island in the agricultural sea.

The town center nothing more than a single stoplight swaying in the wind at a fourway crossing, watching over the few establishments that clung to existence there. Hong Kong, run by a family whose story was never told. Fiesta Mexican. Gary's with its burgers. The pizzeria long gone now, its windows dark and empty like dead eyes. Maxwell and Halford Drug still poured cherry cola like some remnant of an older time. IGA stood charging prices that drove folk twenty miles to Batesburg-Leesville where the Walmart waited like some retail paradise.

Dollar General remained the heart of it all, its fluorescent pulse drawing people from sunup to sundown. Possibilities Furniture & More occupied its corner, the owner's kindness a currency more valuable than money, her two movers like disciples of her trade. Next door the pet groomer tended to the town's companions, washing and clipping away the dust of rural life.

The doctor and the vet practiced their arts in quiet buildings away from the center, treating the living things of Johnston with what tools they had. The elementary school stood alone, releasing its children to other towns once they grew too old for its walls. They were building a park now, two and a half acres of hope for a future that might never come.

No theaters here. No bowling alleys. No places for youth to gather and dream of escape. Just the road through town, quick enough to miss in a blink, like a dream you cant quite remember come morning. The town endured, neither dying nor truly living, suspended in the humid air like a peach not yet ready to fall.

The street runs between two highways like a vein between arteries, carrying the lifeblood of traffic past our house that stands sentinel at the corner where the pavement bends. Tennessee. Small town. The kind of place where folk dont come and go much anymore, like the world done forgot about it somehow. We watch them all from here, me and the wife and the two girls, eleven and fourteen, watching through windows like pale ghosts in a house that's become our world entire.

The neighborhood stretches out before us like some dying thing, houses scattered among trees that was here long before any of us. Folk go about their business like they always have. Mowing grass till the machines sound like theyre calling to one another across the yards, March through October when the grass finally yields to the coming cold. Then the leaves begin their death march, drifting down in browns and reds till they carpet the ground and we burn them, the smoke rising up like prayers in the autumn air.

Winter ain't what it used to be. More like autumn that won't die, hanging on past its time. The children still find their way down the hill on sleds when the snow comes, which ain't often anymore. Most days its just bikes and dogs and walkers moving through the street like specters in some half-remembered dream.

The garage stands at the back of the house where I work on my truck, doors open to the world like wounds. Front door might as well be sealed shut for all we use it. Holidays bring the strangers, cars lined up and down the street like mourners at a wake. Thanksgiving. Christmas. Mother's Day. They come and they go and the street returns to its silence.

Sometimes we cook out back, smoke rising from the grill like signals to whoever might be watching. Sometimes we play in the rain, the water washing away whatever sins we might have gathered. But mostly we just watch. Watch the cars pass, watch the seasons change, watch the neighbors move through their lives like actors in some great theater we cant quite understand. This street, this life, this endless procession of days. It'd be perfect if it weren't for the traffic. But nothing's perfect anymore. Maybe it never was.

The land stretches out brown and dead, nothing but dirt far as the eye can see. Dirt and more dirt still. Nobody knows what it means less they lived here, less they woke each morning to that vast brown emptiness, the rare patch of green lawn standing like some rich man's mockery of nature itself. Back in the nineties the houses stood far apart, scattered like bones across the waste. Still do mostly, though new structures rise up now, civilization creeping in slow but steady like some horrid tide.

Place grows more citified with each passing season though that's the way of things everywhere now. Folk here are kindly enough but like anywhere there's good and there's bad and there's worse. My patch is ringed with old folk, friendly enough, marking this as one of the better places though that don't mean much. The stores are all them chain operations. Food For Less. Smart and Final. Nothing fancy. You want that kind of thing you got to travel and even then.

Construction work's what keeps most alive out here. Not from reading no statistics but from watching. Makes sense with all this empty space waiting to be filled. That thought sits in my gut like a stone. Left the big city to get away from all that. Now I work construction myself, hanging drywall and ceiling bars, watching the spread of it.

But it's the animals make this place what it is. Folk come here for different reasons but mainly it's the stark beauty of it, the challenge of it. Desert's got its own rules, its own way of being. Got creatures living here can't live nowhere else. Human folk best learn to live alongside em proper. My young ones took to it natural. Even now they're out there hunting lizards and desert bugs like some primitive tribesmen, learning the ways of this hard land.

Town's got its attractions if you want em. County fair comes through regular. Folks head up to Wrightwood when they need to see snow, learn to slide down mountains for sport. Museum's got old bones and Indian things, tells how this place came to be what it is. But that ain't what matters. What matters is the desert itself, vast and empty, waiting patient as stone while we scurry bout building our little lives atop it, temporary as morning dew.

The campus stretches out before him like some vast concrete labyrinth. Gray and godless. He reckons it his neighborhood though he knows such words mean little now. Not like the neighborhoods of old where families dwelt in their separate houses and children played in streets now long dead and gone.

The buildings rise up like ancient monoliths. Three kinds there are. The apartments first, stacked two stories high with their identical windows staring out blind and dark. Twenty souls perhaps in each one, though he cannot be sure. Then the houses proper, scattered few and far between, where the old guard dwells. Alumni they're called, though such words mean little now. And last the dormitories, great concrete hives where hundreds sleep two by two in cells no bigger than prison holds.

The people here are of all kinds and colors, though that matters little now. The elders keep to their houses while the young ones crowd the dorms and the ones between take the apartments. Like some great sorting of souls, each to their designated place in this concrete purgatory.

There are stores too, though they ain't like the stores of old. Places to eat and places to buy clothes marked with symbols of learning. A single park remains, kept clean by some unspoken covenant among those who dwell here. At night it lies empty and dark, the swings creaking soft in the wind like hanging men.

He studies it all through eyes grown tired of looking. This is his neighborhood now, this place of learning and waiting. Self-contained and sealed off from the world beyond like some great ark adrift on a sea of asphalt and concrete. He knows no other home now. Knows too that home is just a word, like neighborhood, like community. Words that mean less with each passing day.

But still they persist here, all of them, in their concrete caves and their borrowed beds. Still they wake each morning and go about their rituals of learning, as if such things still matter in a world grown strange and cold. Perhaps they do. Perhaps this is all that's left to them now. This place. These people. This neighborhood that ain't really a neighborhood at all.

No sidewalks here. The world tilts downward from where the house stands like some ancient sentinel at the peak of what they call the workout hill, though there aint nothing about exercise in its nature. Just gravity and the weight of things. Folk walk in the road cause there aint no choice about it. The pavement's broke and scarred like an old fighter's face, pocked with holes that'll tear the heart out of any vehicle daring enough to pass. Above it all hang the wires, patched and mended like a vagrant's coat, victims of countless storms that rake through here regular as grief. The repairmen come and go and the wires get uglier.

Trees rise up everywhere. Tall evergreens that folk hate cause they block the view of the water. They cut em down with a vengeance born of greed, building their glass houses higher and higher, reaching up like drowning men for a glimpse of the bay. At sunset the water burns like molten copper but mostly its hidden behind clouds thick as wool blankets, the light filtering through like some weak memory of brightness. The damp claims everything here. Moss creeps across the world like a plague, turning roofs and cars and metal to green fur. Left my own vehicle out once and nature took it back, took three hours of scraping to reclaim it from the green.

Aint many children. Just old folk waiting out their days, and dogs. Dogs everywhere, running wild and free, sneaking into houses like thieves through any door left open by the careless. Found one in my living room once, staring at me like I was the intruder. The rabbits too, big as cats some of them, tearing up gardens till my cats hunted em down. Birds pass through - sparrows, hummingbirds small as thoughts, and sometimes a hawk floating overhead till the crows drive it off like some dark army protecting their territory.

Down by the water there's places to eat what the bay provides, though there aint much beach to speak of. Just rocks for throwing into the gray water. The opposite shore sits out there in the mist like some dream of civilization, close enough to see but too far to touch. Just watching and waiting while the fog rolls in.

They say Bensonhurst aint hard to find. The trains come and go like metal serpents through the concrete canyons of Brooklyn, carrying souls worn thin by the city's weight. The streets lay dark and solemn beneath perpetual sheets of gray sky.

The neighborhood bears its own particular darkness. Not the darkness of empty places but the darkness of too many souls pressed together in weathered buildings that stand like tired sentinels. Asian letters flash their neon promises from every storefront, marking territory claimed over decades past. Supermarkets and laundromats line the streets like prayer beads on a rosary, each one identical to the last, each one necessary as breath.

Where I stand now there are four markets within sight of each other, their windows fogged with steam and voices speaking in tongues I do not know. The people here are pilgrims all, first and second sons of immigrants seeking something they cannot name. The businesses belong mostly to the Asians now, their industry as relentless as the tide.

They built a park nearby. Ten courts for basketball where children play their endless games. Soccer fields stretch out like dead grass seas. Handball courts stand silent as tombs until filled with the echo of rubber balls and young voices. A fountain spits water in summer months, blessing the children with temporary baptism.

The buildings here are low and humble. No glass towers reach for God. Just homes stacked two deep where families weather the long nights. Music bleeds from passing cars like wounds, engines roar their defiance at the dawn. Nights bring their own particular terrors. The streets grow teeth. Men with hollow eyes seek prey among the shadows.

I knew their violence once. Felt fists against flesh, learned the taste of blood and fear. Now thieves hunt packages left on stoops like carrion birds. And everywhere the dogs leave their offerings, ignored by masters who have forgotten the meaning of civilization. The city fines mean nothing here where law is just a whisper carried away by wind.

Watch your step in Bensonhurst. The concrete remembers everything it has seen.

You got to know what weird means in Portland Oregon fore you can understand the place itself. Written up on some building that serves pizza and liquor and flesh and music and probably breaks half dozen laws doing it are the words Keep Portland Weird. Some folk say its bout remembering the old days when the city wasnt so known and wasnt so dear and folk could make something different of themselves here. Others hear it like a calling. Come to Portland theyd say. We'll call you weird here too but we'll mean it kind.

The Californians came with their money and their condos rose like concrete weeds from the earth but Portland stayed weird all the same. Not that weird means kind exactly. More like accepting things others wont accept. We got our modern ways same as anywhere. Chinese goods in the stores same as anywhere else in this godforsaken country. Weird aint about that.

In my part of town the houses stand painted in colors that'd make a carnival jealous. Gardens growing wild with herbs and flowers pressing up through cracks in the sidewalk like nature trying to take back whats hers. And there's them free boxes. Just cardboard mostly though sometimes plastic. Like offerings to whatever gods still care to look down on us. Books and clothes mostly but could be anything. Something bout walking these streets in Southeast makes you believe in magic again. Least thats how I see it but Im just one kind of weird in this city of thousands.

Some folk wouldnt touch nothing from a sidewalk box. They do their yoga with goats. Yes real goats. Or they go watch them Timbers kick a ball round a field. Portland's got all kinds. Dreamers and drunks and them that cant tell the difference no more.

The rain comes most days. Gray and constant like God crying. Brings the darkness in peoples minds. We got drugs here sure. Got homeless too. More than most places cause we try to help em but we dont help enough. Never enough. The rest of us we care bout em or we hate em depending on the day. In that we aint weird at all. Just human. Poor sorry humans same as anywhere else.

The mountains stand sentinel. Always there in the north, bearing witness to the coming and going of light like some ancient gods carved from stone. A man might forget them in the daily toil of existence but they remain, unmoved and unchanging, like thoughts in the mind of God. When the weight of living becomes too much they call out with their silence and a man might look upon them and find some measure of peace in their permanence.

I came here first as a young man. The university stretched out below them peaks like some congregation before an altar. Fine buildings there were and pools of water reflecting the sky and trees that had stood longer than any man's memory but it was them mountains that held dominion over all. The town beneath grew like weeds in the shadow of stone. Coffee houses with their bitter smell where young folk bent over books in the small hours. The downtown with its old brick worn smooth by time and weather, buildings pressed together like folk huddled against the cold. For them few blocks it was like some greater city had sprouted up out of the quiet earth but that feeling passed quick as it came once you walked past the library.

Memories collect in such places like water in a basin. Some sweet and some bitter. Walking with friends past playground swings gone to rust in the darkness after studying all night. Running through crowded streets to catch some picture show in that fancy theater. But there were darker times too. Sitting by them ponds at two in the morning watching ducks and turtles going about their business while inside your head the darkness grows. Watching them creatures each with their purpose while your own seems lost in the vastness of living.

So I walked. Past the pond and the park and them little houses all lined up neat like graves. When I reached the main road the sun was coming up, painting everything in fire and shadow. Palm trees stood like sentries and above it all them mountains remained. Cutting into that fire-touched sky like they had done since before man walked upright. And something in that permanence spoke without speaking. Some truth older than words about carrying on. About enduring.

You wouldnt see it at first passing. Just retail facades and empty lots where folk once shopped for organic produce and whatnot. But beyond the dead Whole Foods and past them hotels that only breathe life when summer brings the reunions of blood kin, there's a whole world moving and breathing. Streets lined with apartment buildings like great concrete monoliths laid out in perfect succession, each one watching the other in some kind of architectural vigil. First ones got darkness in their history. Best leave them be. Truth aint always what papers tell.

Beyond these stands another world. Silent. Unknown to most. College buildings squatting low against the earth, students dragging themselves through iron gates that screech like dying things in the dawn light. Traffic backed up while morning folk curse from their vehicles, their words lost in the heavy air.

Road ends at a T, park on one side and them bone-mending folks on the other. Their porch with its wicker chairs and that ceiling fan turning slow circles in air thick as molasses. Children spinning themselves through the grass like gyroscopes while bees work the flowers growing wild by the roadside. Old ones walking their dogs, eyeing the young ones on their boards with suspicion born of years. Girls gather like birds on playground metal, speaking secrets about boys and whatever moving pictures light up their phones these days.

Strip mall stands sentinel. Sushi joint never full but keeping on somehow. Swimming store. Nail place. All of it lined up neat like artifacts in some museum of modern living. Frozen yogurt spot drawing them young ones like moths, their cups sweating in the heat while they show off on wheels and breathe sweet smoke into the heavy air, thinking themselves immortal.

This here's a piece of the old south. Time moves different here. Like molasses in winter. Everything preserved in amber, waiting. Just waiting.

The houses stood like ancient sentinels. Some whole and some split asunder yet joined still in their weathered communion. Small yards stretched before them and narrow drives lay alongside like pale wounds in the earth. They spoke of times past when suburban living was the dream that held this country in its grip but that dream was loosening now like a rope worn thin by time and weather. Yet these neighborhoods persisted. Called out their testament to any who'd listen that the dream hadnt died entirely.

The people walked different now. Less hope in their step. Yards gone wild where once they'd been kept pristine but still the cars sat in drives two by two like creatures waiting for the flood. Children played in the streets as if the world ended at its borders. The school stood ninety years strong conjuring futures in the young while stirring ghosts in the old. Churches sparse and empty but the basketball courts filled with life and motion. Houses different as thumbprints but kindred somehow in their bones.

Super A they called it. Run by Yemenis, perhaps the only Arab folk for miles in this sea of black faces. Streets wide as rivers where children played their games, scattering like starlings when cars approached. Folk here could trace their blood back generations in this place. Tell tales of when neighbor knew neighbor like kin.

Where once stood a karate school now stood a pharmacy. Dreams of martial glory faded with the moving pictures that spawned them. Pills took their place. The old theatre still showed its ancient reels, saved from crowds by young folk's scorn but blessed by the elders who found comfort in its dimness, away from children's eyes.

A single highway passed through but never touched ground here. Young ones wanted an exit built but the elders knew better. Knew that progress was just another word for death. They were building a new school now. Talking of mascots. Some spoke of a mechanical man with a country drawl and a cabin of logs. But in this place nothing was ever truly new. Just old things wearing different faces.

The city sprawls vast and merciless before him. Buildings rise like concrete monoliths against a gray sky that holds neither promise nor redemption. Streets wind through the maze of steel and glass, some bearing names in foreign tongues - Koreatown, Little Armenia - each a world sealed within itself. Traffic moves like blood through clogged arteries, two hours to traverse ten miles, the vehicles packed together in mindless congregation.

He studies the neighborhood from his window. Orthodox Jews in black coats moving like shadows through the morning light. Soviet refugees carrying their histories like wounds that won't heal. Rainbow flags hanging limp in windows, testaments to loves that dare speak their names. All of them moving through the same dead space, breathing the same tired air.

The parks stand like green islands in the concrete sea. Children play there still, their voices carrying across time itself, reminiscent of days when he too ran wild with the neighbor boy, before the world grew cold and strange. Now neighbors pass like ghosts, nameless, faceless, sealed behind walls and doors that never open.

Construction cranes loom against the horizon like ancient siege machines. New towers rising, steel bones reaching skyward, while below the streets grow more congested, more choked with each passing season. Parking spaces become rare as gold. The city devours itself and grows hungry still.

Houses crouch between the towers - single homes, duplexes, small apartment blocks - each one a universe unto itself. Some dating back to times when people still knew their neighbors' names, when communities weren't just words in real estate listings. But those days are gone now, gone like smoke in the wind, like all things must go.

The streets fill and empty, fill and empty, an endless tide of humanity washing through the concrete canyons. Each soul carrying its own story, its own burden, moving through the vastness alone. The city holds them all, indifferent as God, while the sun wheels overhead in a sky the color of beaten lead.

She asked where everything was as we drove past the endless corn. This is it, I told her. She'd never known such emptiness, coming from a place where stores stood within arms reach of home. The corn stretched out beyond sight, row upon row like soldiers in formation, waiting. I told her bout growing up here in Ohio country, watching recognition dawn in her eyes like the slow light of morning.

Past the water-filled quarry the houses rose up from the earth, brick and stucco set back from the road on half-acre plots tended like holy ground. Spring brought forth flowers planted by hands that knew the seasons, knew the trees that died and lived again with each turn of the year. Mercedes machines gleamed in driveways like chrome beasts drinking the midday sun.

The Korean lived three houses down, always outside, always singing above his mower's drone. Doctor once, they said. Now just a man who'd lost pieces of himself to time, melding with the grass and his green John Deere like some strange hybrid creature born of lawn and machine.

Our house stood grey against grey sky. Geese claimed the side yard til the terrier drove them off. Behind lay the stream that fed the quarry, carrying bullfrog song and cattle lowing from distant pastures. Cross the wooden bridge we built with our hands and you'd find yourself in untamed country. Wild flowers and herbs grew there among trees that knew no master.

This was where childhood lived. Where we built fortresses in trees and stalked imaginary prey. Where neighborhood children appeared like spirits through the brush, companions in our wild games.

Winter came hard and merciless but brought its own terrible beauty. The yard transformed from living green to dead white wilderness. Trees that once bloomed pink and purple stood naked now, their dark bones reaching toward leaden sky. Snow came in the night like judgment, covering all. My sister's angels lay scattered in drifts while snowmen stood sentinel. We warred with packed ice, building frozen ramparts to shield our arsenal of winter weapons. Here in our sealed white world we played at life while real life waited somewhere beyond the fields, beyond the corn, beyond our knowing. We were children then. We knew nothing of what waited.
